The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we report the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two myxozoans, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to the model parasite P. hydriforme. In addition, our analyses reveal that myxozoans have one of the smallest reported animal genomes and that they have lost many genes involved in development and cell differentiation. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune system is one of the main factors that contribute to their pathogenicity. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) and, consequently, to impair the antiviral response. Our results unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune system and may help in the development of strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The voltage-gated proton channel (Hv1) is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, but the magnitude of the effects is highly uncertain. Here, we use a statistical model to project the future variability of maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries under two different scenarios of global warming. We find that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially, and in some countries, the variability will be much larger than it is today. This higher variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the top four maize-exporting countries to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the degree to which different species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of wild and domestic LMH in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in size and digestive physiology, LMH consumed different plant species, and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results have implications for the management of LMH in African savanna and beyond.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and many plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most common forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the plastic debris on the open ocean surface is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but in much smaller amounts than expected. This is due to the selective removal of the smaller plastic fragments by the food web and the ocean interior.

The solar system formed 4.6 Ga ago. The history of the solar system is imprinted in the composition of the rocks that formed it. We determined the age of 40 large presolar grains that formed in the interstellar medium before the solar system formed. The grains have cosmogenic nuclides that were produced by the interaction of cosmic rays with the interstellar medium. The grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. The grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to offspring correlates with an increase in reproductive output. This is true for both the mother and the father. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in resource availability. Instead, it is due to an increase in metabolic power.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in the brain of a mouse model of MSA. This suggests that VX-765 could be a promising drug for the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the human body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells and is the only cell type in the body that is in direct contact with the blood. The endothelium is therefore the most important cell type in the body and is the focus of this study. This study reveals that the endothelium is a highly connected network of cells that is organized in a way that allows for rapid and robust communication between the cells. This organization is effective for both local and global communication and is therefore critical for the control of cardiovascular activity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modelers. We present the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 signals, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These signals are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This study shows that the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels is crucial for this allosteric communication. The Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This study provides a deeper understanding of the molecular basis of the gating of potassium channels and opens the door to the development of new drugs for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is constantly changing in response to the host’s environment and diet. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host is not fully understood, but it is thought to be important in the regulation of the host’s metabolism and immune system. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics and other antimicrobial compounds, that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are important contributors to the natural product diversity of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is of great importance for the development of smart and intelligent devices. In this work, we propose a synthesis, fabrication, and assembly strategy to design and manufacture composite structures with multiple material phases that can precisely realize arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture structures with complex and programmable behaviors. The strategy can be applied to a wide range of applications, such as soft robotics, soft robotics, and soft robotics.

The hemoglobin system is one of the most important physiological systems in the human body. It is responsible for the transport of oxygen throughout the body. The hemoglobin system is also a target for the treatment of anemia in a variety of diseases. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key element in the heterochronic regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that SREBP1-mediated ferroptosis resistance can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway may be a promising strategy for overcoming ferroptosis resistance in cancer. This strategy may be applicable to other forms of cancer, and may also be useful for the treatment of other diseases. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure and the most common cause of death worldwide. Hypertension is also the most common risk factor for heart failure. Hypertension is characterized by remodeling of the vascular wall, which is driven by the Ca2+ signaling machinery. In this study, we show that the three major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate the Ca2+ signaling machinery in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), leading to vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of LCCBs in the development of cardiovascular diseases and may lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of hypertension.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but the policy failed to reverse the decline of these species. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this study provide a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes and to other targets of interest. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, making it difficult to train the network and to apply it to problems with large images. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the impact of environmental change on biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We show that the evolution of the species flock is linked to the evolution of the climate system, and that the lake underwent large-scale changes in hydroclimate over the last 1.3 My.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is a growing phenomenon in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime can have a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices can phase-delay the circadian clock, suppress melatonin, and reduce the amount of sleep. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) boundary is one of the most important events in the Earth’s history, and it is widely accepted that the YDB is associated with a bolide impact. However, the bolide impact hypothesis has been challenged by the lack of evidence for a large impact in the YDB deposits. Here, we show that the osmium isotope composition of the YDB deposits is consistent with a terrestrial origin of the osmium. The YDB spherules are derived from the impact, and the osmium in the spherules is likely terrestrial in origin.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still to be determined. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the function of CTLA-4 is not limited to the early development of autoimmunity but also in the maintenance of tolerance.

The order Coleoptera is arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. Here, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of beetles, including the first phylogeny of the group based on 4,800 genes. We show that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes in their genomes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE ε4 allele, which increases the risk of AD by ∼12-fold. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system that is highly phagocytic. We also found that APOE alleles are highly dependent on each other in controlling the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular basis for the role of APOE in AD risk. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,400 km in diameter and 1,300 km in height. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3, and is the only part of the Earth that is not in dynamic equilibrium with the rest of the planet. The inner core is a paradox because it is formed by a process that is not thermodynamically stable. This study provides a solution to the paradox, which is that the inner core is formed by two steps of nucleation.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not well understood, the drug is increasingly being legalized in the United States and elsewhere. This study provides evidence that the brain’s reactivity to the drug is reduced in people who use marijuana chronically. The reduced reactivity might contribute to the drug’s addictive properties and negative emotional states.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. We therefore sought to understand how language is processed in the brain. We found that deep learning models that predict well on a language task also predict well on the brain data. This suggests that language processing in the brain is fundamentally predictive. We also found that the architecture of the model matters for the strength of the relationship between the model and the brain. These results provide a new perspective on the human brain and language processing. They also suggest that deep learning models may be a powerful tool for understanding the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that the algorithms used to train deep networks are not stable themselves. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they can compute stable deep networks with great accuracy. This is a major step forward in understanding the nature of deep learning.

The classic experiment that is the subject of this paper is a prime example of the pitfalls of uncritically accepting the results of a study. It is also a case study in the dangers of overreliance on flawed research. The paper discusses the study’s critical design flaws, which were not noticed at the time of the study’s publication. It also discusses the dangers of overreliance on a study that is cited more often than it is read.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for more than a century, and it is now clear that it is the cause of the disease. However, the origin of leprosy is still a mystery, and the cause of the disease in some patients remains unknown. We have sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico, and compared it with that of the better-characterized Mycobacterium leprae. We find that the two organisms are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions, despite their ancient separation. This suggests that the two organisms are still capable of causing disease, and that they may be the cause of the same disease in different populations. This study has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human genome and the evolution of the disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a fundamental problem of fundamental importance. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a major step forward in the study of the entanglement dynamics, and it opens the door to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is based on the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which is the cause of the disease. This study describes a vaccine candidate that is based on the same virus, but has been modified to be more attenuated. This modification, which is achieved by the use of synonymous suboptimal codons, results in a vaccine that is more protective than the wild-type virus.

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, was one of the deadliest pandemics in human history. The disease spread rapidly through human populations, leading to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death, ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague and its vectors, which is important for the control of the disease today. It also provides a framework for the study of other vector-borne diseases.

The evolution of brain size is a key topic in the study of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain numbers, which are the basic units of information processing, has been neglected. This study fills this gap by providing a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of neuron numbers in amniotes, the group that includes birds and mammals. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which it does so is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We find that this ADF-induced torque dramatically enhances severing. A simple model, which faithfully recapitulates our experimental observations, indicates that the ADF-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. This mechanism may be important for many cellular processes, including cytokinesis.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes. They also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by the presence of glucose.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family is spoken, and it is the only place where the Bantu language family is spoken. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the Austronesian and Bantu languages are related to each other and to the languages of Southeast Asia. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, and that the settlement was not homogeneous across the island.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This is a major finding because it suggests that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to the small number of people who are in close contact with each other. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks, the spread of emotions, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions. It also raises questions about the role of emotions in social networks and the spread of emotions in society. (Show more)

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and the structure and function of noncoding RNAs are critical for cell behavior. One of the most common modifications of noncoding RNAs is the pseudouridine (Ψ) modification, which is found in the coding regions of mRNAs. We show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can have a significant impact on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ can promote the low-level synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the reconstituted translation system as well as human cells, and increases the rate of near-cognate Val-tRNAVal reacting on a ΨUU codon. The vast majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions, and our study suggests that one consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ can be to modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for the function of noncoding RNAs and the translation of mRNAs in cells. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the promotion of healthy aging and for the design of interventions to improve the quality of life in older age.

The evolution of aquatic life is a major event in the history of life on land, but the extent to which the aquatic environment constrains the evolution of body size remains unclear. We use a model of the energetic costs and benefits of living in water to show that the evolution of aquatic life is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of this virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature is a key factor in the pathogenesis of the common cold. Here, we show that this temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor signaling pathway, which is activated by the double-stranded RNA of viral RNA sensors. Our findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and therapeutics.

The ability of bacteria to sense and respond to their environment is a key factor in their adaptation to their habitat and in the development of disease. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanochemical sensing system is essential for the development of a surface-associated phenotype, which is required for the pathogen to establish infection. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of bacterial sensing systems and the mechanisms of bacterial adaptation to their environment. They also have implications for the development of new strategies for the control of bacterial infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the number of pesticides available to farmers is constantly growing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of these pesticides in surface water and the risk they pose to aquatic biodiversity. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the biological integrity of global water resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the ecology of the virus and the animals that may act as reservoirs. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the identification of multiple lineages of the virus in deer and humans. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of the development of hydropower, the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, and the challenges of building sustainable hydropower. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is associated with chronic neuroinflammation. However, the origin of this inflammation is not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric forms of amyloid-β (Aβ) secreted by neurons are the primary cause of the neuroinflammatory response in the brain. This is significant because neurons are the most vulnerable cell type in AD, and the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is a direct consequence of the progressive loss of their function. Our findings have important implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the study of the evolution of animal husbandry and the spread of agriculture. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest known site where chickens were widely exploited for economic purposes. The results are supported further by an extensive survey of the Southern Levant, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. This work shows that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct steps, each of which is a native-like intermediate. The intermediate is a key step in the folding process, and it is a major step in the folding of the protein.

The presence of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in cells is a common indicator of stress. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap structure from RNA, ApaH, is inactivated by the conditions that enable accumulation of Np4. We also show that the enzyme responsible for removing Np4-capped RNAs, RppH, prefers to decape them over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This preference is due to a unique mechanism of substrate recognition, in which the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, is the site of attack. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanisms involved in the dysfunction of the immune system are still not fully understood. We demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore the immune system during sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global biomass of humans and the need for a more complete census of the biomass of wild mammals. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

We introduce a continuous model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it exhibits a scaling limit that is a certain limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts and show that our model is a continuous version of the sandpile model. We also discuss the connection between our model and pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and it is difficult to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be completely closed. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The study of plant immunity has been revolutionized by the discovery of the plant immune peptides, which are small, cysteine-rich peptides that are expressed in the plant immune system and have been shown to have a variety of functions. However, the structural basis of their function is still largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of a plant immune peptide, NCR044, and show that it has a unique structure and exhibits potent antifungal activity. This work provides a structural basis for the function of plant immune peptides and opens up the possibility of developing them as a new class of fungicides.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the male–female interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome after mating, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of male–female interactions and the evolution of the male–female interface. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a disorder of VWF function. The results also suggest that the conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This is a significant result for the field of biophysics. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and allows for the discovery of associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will allow for the study of the role of viruses in human health, and will provide a resource for the study of the human virome for years to come.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The observed water cloud profiles identify that due to air entrainment its vertical structure is not perfectly adiabatic, as assumed by many current retrieval methods. Our ACI analysis shows increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. Here, we provide a new method for reconstructing the temperature history of the Earth based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the main targets of drugs. The pore gate of an ion channel is the main site of drug binding and the main determinant of channel function. The pore gate is composed of two gates, one for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation/recovery. In this study, we found that the pore gate of the K+ channel, the BK channel, is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 200 million cases and 600,000 deaths each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to survive and multiply, and the current standard treatment is ineffective in many areas of the world. Here, we show that the malaria parasite primes the red blood cell surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up a number of exciting avenues for future research. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering, which offers a new route to control its electronic and optical properties. This work provides a new paradigm for the control of the electronic and optical properties of diamond.

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza disease is a topic of great interest. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases the severity of influenza disease. We also show that this effect is dependent on the host immune response, and that the host immune response is impaired by low humidity. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of influenza disease severity and may lead to the development of strategies to mitigate the severity of influenza disease. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this structure is weak. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the formation of a sentence is consistent with a model of a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be important for understanding the development of language and the acquisition of language in children.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation is important for tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin, which are genetically redundant.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. Here we show that stimulation of LH neurons causes rapid vigorous eating in sated mice. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, but rather in the promotion of overeating.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2) from the atmosphere is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is essential for the growth of all plants. However, the amount of N2 fixed by plants is far below the amount fixed by the microbial communities in the soil, and thus, the potential for synthetically increasing the amount of N2 fixed in agriculture is enormous. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a significant step toward the development of a sustainable nitrogen fertilizer system.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people in the United States alone. The lack of a vaccine has been a major obstacle in containing the pandemic. Here we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits high-affinity antibodies. This protein can be used to generate vaccines that can be manufactured at a large scale, which is critical for global access.

We show that the zebrafish homolog of the human anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) is a ligand for secreted small ALKAL proteins, which are also present in humans. We further demonstrate that the ALKALs are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish and Drosophila eyes. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKals in neural crest development and suggest a role of these receptors in human cancer.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the cause of the Black Death, is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The pathogen’s history is poorly understood because of the scarcity of ancient genomes. Here, we present 17 ancient Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a more complete picture of the pathogen’s evolution during this period. We find that the pathogen was not only present in the Neolithic but also rapidly spread across Eurasia, with a strong correlation between geographical distance and genetic distance. Our results also reveal the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of the pathogen. These data provide a more complete picture of the pathogen’s history and evolution, which is critical for understanding the origins of the Black Death and its impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support

The management of agricultural systems can affect the amount and distribution of soil organic carbon (SOC) in the top meter of soil. In this study, we show that the management of annual cropping systems on a Midwestern Mollisol can be optimized to increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC in the soil profile. We show that the addition of legumes and manure, the incorporation of cover crops, and the rotation of crops and livestock can increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC in the soil profile. These results highlight the potential of diverse, rotationally grazed pasture management to increase SOC storage on Midwestern Mollisols. This study provides a framework for the management of agricultural systems to increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC in the soil profile. This framework can be used to develop climate-smart agricultural systems that can mitigate climate change. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses from wildlife to humans. We used a combination of expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify the host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to spillover and spread of viruses in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. In this study, we show that the red color of nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify this compound in the red nectar of two species visited by hummingbirds. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from the late 5th/early 6th century AD from present-day Bavaria, Germany. The analysis of their collective genetic ancestry indicates that women in this group had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. This is particularly striking in women with artificial skull deformations, who also differed in visible characteristics. In addition, many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how MERS-CoV spreads to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent future MERS outbreaks. They also provide insights into the evolution of bat coronaviruses and their potential to infect humans.

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common clinical category, and that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV, were also detected. Early detection of chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Our findings highlight the feasibility of pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings and the potential for mNGS to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to investigate other clinical categories, such as respiratory illness, to better understand the regional pathogen landscape and the potential for emerging epidemics. This approach can be used to investigate other clinical categories, such as respiratory illness, to better understand the regional pathogen landscape and the potential for emerging epidemics.

The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to that of S. cerevisiae. However, the stability of the replicative pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. Here, we report the results of a series of kinetic experiments that reveal that the human pol δ holoenzyme is not as stable as its yeast counterpart. This is important because the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to the process of lagging strand replication. Our results suggest that the human replication system is more similar to the replication of the yeast chromosome than previously thought.
The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In this paper, we describe the first experimental demonstration of the evolution of life from RNA.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 years. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods is a key factor in the success of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that the patients with severe and critical COVID-19 had high levels of interleukin 6, which may be the cause of the inflammatory storm. Tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, can reduce the levels of interleukin 6 and improve the clinical symptoms of the patients.

The role of natural products in the ecology of fungi is well established, but the role of these compounds in the homeostasis of metal micronutrients is less well understood. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) of Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide compounds that bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the homeostasis of copper, and that the isocyanide products of the xan BGC may mediate interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in metal homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings have implications for our understanding of the ecology of fungi and the role of natural products in these interactions. They also have implications for our understanding of the role of natural products in human disease.

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock in Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) phase that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of this phase in a sedimentary rock in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment is possibly due to the cogenetic origin of the tridymite, plagioclase, cristobalite, and other phases. The presence of amorphous silica, mixed-cation salts, and oxides, and magnetite in the same rock is possibly due to multiple aqueous infiltrations. The presence of post-lithification anhydrous sulfate and carbonate veins is consistent with the presence of aqueous fluids in the sediment source region and/or at the site of deposition.

The impact of frost on plants and animals is a major concern for agriculture, forestry, and wildlife management. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are also changing accordingly. Our findings can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a recently discovered subset of CD4+ T cells that are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, Th17 cells are also capable of transitioning to a Th1-like phenotype, which is associated with the resolution of inflammation. We show here that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis, and that this requires the development of Th1-like cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential therapies. This will enable the identification of disease-causing genes and the development of personalized therapies.

The gut microbiota of ticks is critical for the acquisition of pathogens and the development of the tick life cycle. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that is expressed in the gut of the vector, the Ixodes scapularis tick. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work also provides a potential target for the development of tick control strategies. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is still controversial. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan and the evolution of the tail.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere is increasing with tropospheric temperature, implying that the water vapor in the stratosphere is also warming the climate. This is a significant finding, as it implies that the water vapor feedback is larger than previously thought. This finding has implications for the future of the climate, as it implies that the climate will be more sensitive to increases in greenhouse gases.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and even to yellow and green. In this study, we show that the green color of many vertebrates is due to the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a molecule that is normally found in the blood. This discovery provides a molecular explanation for the evolution of green color in vertebrates, and opens the door to a better understanding of the evolution of color in vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of breast cancer, and are thought to be responsible for the recurrence of the disease after treatment. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates m6A, in breast cancer cells. ALKBH5 expression is dependent on hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α, and is necessary for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cell properties. Thus, our findings suggest that HIF-dependent ALKBH5 expression may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. This paper reports the results of a noninvasive method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. The method is simple, objective, and noninvasive, and it can be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in a wide range of objects.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive production of proinflammatory cytokines and the dysregulation of the intestinal immune system. The intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) are the main barrier between the host and the intestine lumen, and the intestinal immune system is mainly located in the IECs. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays an important role in the regulation of intestinal homeostasis. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that deletion of RORα leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. These findings provide insights into the epigenetic regulation of RORα/NF-κB signaling in IECs and the therapeutic strategies for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with ACE2, the receptor–binding domain, and the furin processing site. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation that may facilitate receptor binding. These results provide insights into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and the Black and Latino populations have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.
