The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the key to understanding the properties of matter. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. We also show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We show that our results are explicative and predictive of the chemical behavior of the elements under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, but the implications for the global carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, such as population growth and migration, can suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective under lower emission scenarios, highlighting the importance of mitigating greenhouse gas emissions to avoid further warming. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to better understand the effects of climate change on fire regimes.

The provision of nutrients to microbial communities associated with epithelial surfaces is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate the composition of their microbiota. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent bacteria. We also show that the provision of this glycan is restricted to a specific time of day, which is linked to the maturation of the symbiotic organ. These results provide a mechanistic explanation for the regulation of the activities of epithelial microbiota, and they suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy used by animals to control the composition of their microbial communities. This study also highlights the importance of glycans in the regulation of the immune system.

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a generative model to identify the topic that generated a sequence of words. We then use the topic to identify the gender bias of the topic and the gender bias of the topic in the data. Our method is flexible and broadly applicable to many domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in human history, is often understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. Here, we show that the Black Death was the result of repeated introductions of the bacterium into European harbors, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results provide evidence for the importance of climate-driven reintroductions of the plague bacterium into European harbors, and suggest that the disease was not only the consequence of a single introduction.

Asteroids are a group of marine invertebrates that are of economic and ecological importance. In recent years, a disease has been observed that has led to the mass mortality of populations of at least 20 species. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by the sea stars themselves.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most common cancers in the world, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of targets for treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. Here, we show that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Furthermore, we show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can be used to treat primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach could be used in combination with other therapies, such as chemotherapy, to treat AML. Thus, IL1RAP could be a promising target for the development of novel and more efficient therapies for AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic diversity is from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations. The settlement history of Madagascar is also complex, with a recent population growth and a sex-biased colonization. In addition, we found that the genetic structure of the Malagasy population is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several independent events. These results provide insights into the human history of Madagascar and the settlement of the island.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (denoted GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This work provides insight into the mechanism of action of the AzuC protein and the role of the RNA in carbon utilization. It also demonstrates the importance of considering the protein and RNA

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is conducted by a large network of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We demonstrate that the CPC can be used to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the CPC can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our findings have implications for the monitoring of agricultural production and the early detection of crop anomalies, and can be extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is able to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is able to bind information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The response of soil respiration to climate warming is a key uncertainty in our understanding of the global carbon cycle. In this study, we provide the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, and use these data to investigate the temperature response of soil respiration to climate warming. Our analysis reveals that the temperature response of soil respiration to climate warming is highly variable across biomes, with no consistent evidence of acclimation in all biomes. Our results suggest that future increases in global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. These results highlight the importance of understanding the temperature response of soil respiration in a wide range of biomes, and the need for further research to improve our mechanistic understanding of this process.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of life on Earth. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was caused by a combination of natural and anthropogenic factors. However, the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the drought risk in SSA remains uncertain. Here, we use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent droughts and their future projections.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major scientific event of the last decade. The first naturally occurring quasicrystals were found in meteorites, and the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems has been driven by the search for new materials with unique properties. Here, we report the discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of the atomic bomb.

(Bacterio)chlorophylls are the light-harvesting pigments of photosynthesis. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is a diiron protein, the other an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein. Here we show that the diiron protein is a cyclase in plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria, whereas the [4Fe-4S] cluster protein is a cyclase in anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria. These findings provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), the most common autoimmune disease of the CNS. In this study, we found that ASK1, a kinase that is activated by a variety of stress signals, plays a critical role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation in the central nervous system. We also found that ASK1 in microglia plays a major role in the generation of neuroinflammation, and that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the maintenance of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occur when conditions are warm are more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. Finally, we show that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability that dry precipitation years are also extremely warm.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the autism-risk genes and their functions and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies for autism. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, but its physiological role has remained elusive. Here, we show that loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein and gain-of-function mutations in the Ca2+ sensing protein are associated with distinct clinical phenotypes. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions.

The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates can spread in a transcellular manner, and that this spreading is dependent on the internalization of aggregates. We also show that the internalization of aggregates is dependent on the endocytic machinery, and that this is important for the spread of disease. These findings provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats remain largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent immunomodulator that inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-leukotriene-A4 hydrolase. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and may lead to the development of new antiviral drugs. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a critical pathway for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolic enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and show that this inhibitor blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts. We also show that the one-carbon donor, formate, is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We show that formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a disease in which the one-carbon donor is a targetable metabolic deficiency. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results provide a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in cancer therapy, and a target for the treatment of lymphoma.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, and the presence of these inclusions is a key diagnostic feature of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The band structures of the photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic and the first aquatic flowering plants were probably small. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology, but the evolution of the human parvovirus B19 (B19V) has been a subject of debate. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes from humans who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. Further, we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also provides a unique resource for future studies of the evolution of B19V. (Show more)
We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with climate change.

Pain is a major public health problem, and the number of Americans reporting pain is rising. However, the elderly are reporting less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that the elderly are not less pain-prone than those in midlife, but rather that the elderly are more pain-prone than those born earlier. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate of tryptophan synthase with indole, a reaction that is the defining step in the mechanism of this enzyme. This study demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates, and to provide insight into the reaction pathway. This approach can be applied to a wide range of enzymes, and will be a powerful tool for mechanistic enzymology in the future.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of RNA-dependent RNA polymerase that was shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection is effective in preventing and treating the disease, respectively. These data support the development of remdesivir for a clinical trial in humans. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing outbreak.

The provision of nutrients to microbial communities associated with epithelial surfaces is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate the composition of their microbiota. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent bacteria. We also show that the provision of this glycan is restricted to a specific time of day, which is linked to the maturation of the symbiotic organ. These results provide a mechanism by which epithelial-associated microbes are regulated, and they suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general mechanism used by animals to control the composition of their microbiota. This study also highlights the importance of glycans in the regulation of the immune system.

This study shows that it is possible to reduce the use of school suspensions, which are costly to students and society. The study also shows that it is possible to change teachers’ mindsets about discipline, which can be a barrier to reducing suspensions. The study is important because it shows that it is possible to reduce suspensions in a way that is scalable and sustainable.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles and that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings are of great importance for understanding the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis and cancer. They also provide a valuable resource for the development of therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked the sequential proteolytic events required for virus entry. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Therefore, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can lead to a proportional increase in sales. This has important implications for the food service industry and for the broader field of environmental and behavioral economics. It suggests that, by making a few simple changes to the physical environment, it may be possible to increase the proportion of meals that are more sustainable for the environment and healthier for the diner. This approach could be applied in a wide range of settings, including hospitals, schools, and workplaces. The approach could also be applied to other areas of behavior, such as the use of energy and water. The approach could also be applied to other areas of behavior, such as the use of energy and water.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, the effects of vote-by-mail are not well understood. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the molecular basis of the disease and the virus that causes it. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides a better understanding of the molecular basis of the disease and the virus that causes it. It also provides a resource for the structural biology community to study the structure and function of SARS-CoV-2 proteins. This structure will be useful for the development of vaccines and therapeutics.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, and knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in the cortex, leading to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) and cerebral edema. We also show that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into cortical astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using transfected cells, we show that transfected CRFR1 contributes to edema via transfected AQP4. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We live in an age of big data. The size of the data sets is growing rapidly, and the complexity of the statistical models is increasing even faster. We describe a new challenge that arises in this setting. We call it “selective inference” because it requires us to set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We illustrate the challenge and its solution in the context of forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that our work will encourage the development of new methods for selective inference in the future.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the treatment of ischemic disorders and the regeneration of damaged organs. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the treatment of ischemic disorders and the regeneration of damaged organs. Furthermore, the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study also provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the treatment of ischemic disorders and the regeneration of damaged organs. (Show more)

We report the discovery of a third group of RTKs, named “augmentor,” which are involved in the development of the zebrafish eye. We show that the augmentor ligands are essential for the development of the eye and the body color of the adult fish.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Herein, we found that the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) is required for the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. Specifically, STING deficiency in β-cells caused a loss of nuclear factor of activated T cells 1 (NFATc1) and Pax6, leading to impaired GSIS. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of T2D and suggest that STING might be a potential target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and are responsible for occasional pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles. Our experiments indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is a key step in the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. The lack of conservation of this interaction among influenza A viruses might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This interaction could be a target for antiviral development. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is associated with the development of cardiovascular diseases. The disturbed flow, a key feature of atherosclerosis, is associated with the activation of YAP/TAZ, a key transcription factor in mediating vascular homeostasis. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerosis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Therefore, the findings of this study may lead to the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. (PsycINFO Database Record

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural landscape for millennia. However, in recent decades, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the need for policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 years. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social health of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and productive ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of human activities, including climate change. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This feedback loop is a key factor in the early stages of bleaching, which is a major threat to coral reefs worldwide. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work thus contributes to the conservation of one of the most important ecosystems on Earth.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, which in turn triggers a regenerative response in the microbiome. This leads to a dysbiotic microbiome, which in turn triggers the growth of tumors. Our results identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for the development of strategies to control tumor growth. They also provide a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in host–microbe homeostasis and homeostasis of the intestinal epithelium.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women and the leading cause of cancer death in women. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to chemotherapy. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer.

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is one of the most debated aspects of the last deglaciation. Here we show that the onset of deglaciation was linked to a series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in climate and circulation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions of high food insecurity. Our data can be used to assess the impacts of fishing on biodiversity, to identify the most vulnerable populations to the loss of fisheries, and to prioritize the development of sustainable management plans. Our results highlight the need for a more holistic approach to the management of freshwater ecosystems, which are essential for both food security and biodiversity conservation.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the Mo-based oxide are revealed through the in-depth characterization. The protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of energy storage.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a key feature of the adult nervous system that has been lost in many other organisms. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the well-characterized signaling pathways that mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery provides a unique platform for the discovery of novel genes involved in the control of regeneration.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, and the distribution of recombination events across the genome is a key determinant of the diversity of the next generation. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination events in the genome of a flowering plant, and we show that the pattern of recombination is similar to that in yeast and in mice. These results provide a detailed view of the distribution of recombination in a eukaryotic genome, and they suggest that the process of meiosis has been conserved in the evolution of the eukaryotic cell.

The resting state network (RSN) is a set of brain regions that are strongly connected in the absence of external stimulation. This network has been proposed to be involved in the regulation of attention and memory. In this study, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate the RSN in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was similar to the default mode network, whereas in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients, whereas the subordinate RSNs were activated during task performance. These results provide a direct measure of the organization of the brain in health and disease. They also provide a method for assessing the functional role of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes, which is found on a subset of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded messenger RNA. We show that this cap is not associated with a 7-methylguanosine but rather with nicotinamide, a nitrogenous base found in the vitamin niacin. We also show that this cap is produced cotranscriptionally and is not removed by 5′ processing. These results define a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that it could regulate translation of specific classes of mRNA.

The study of epigenetic mechanisms has been a major focus of research in the last decade. The study of epigenetic alterations in diabetes may help to understand the mechanisms of the metabolic memory phenomenon, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We found that DNA-methylation at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes from people with diabetes persisted for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), the major study that established the benefits of intensive diabetes therapy. These findings support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.
This study provides evidence that FSIP1 is a key regulator of drug sensitivity in TNBC. Our findings may aid in the design of targeted therapies for TNBC.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects the quality of life of millions of people worldwide. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides evidence for the reversibility of the biological and behavioral parameters after a short-term detoxification program. These results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthetic pathways of these compounds are not known, and the contribution of these compounds to the overall flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also report the discovery of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase enzyme that catalyzes the formation of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of these compounds and will be a valuable resource for the development of improved tomato varieties.

We show that the impacts of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance of species. We demonstrate that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to temperature, and that this sensitivity is dependent on the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the thermal tolerance of species in the context of climate change, and suggest that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning will be more severe if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for the formation of place memories, are organized in a distinct manner from other cell types in the superficial layers of MEC. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC neurons in vivo and will be useful for future studies of the functional role of this region.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal, FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT), is required for flowering of the host plant, but not for flowering of the parasitic dodder. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering in plants. It is likely that the flowering signal FT is a common component of the evolution of flowering in plants.

The disease is associated with the degeneration of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, but the mechanisms that lead to this loss are not fully understood. We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We are also creatures of habit, and we often repeat the same behaviors over and over again. In this study, we show that the speed at which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of whether we are connected to them.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and its function is regulated by the internal Ca2+ store and the plasma membrane. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1), a Ca2+ sensor, is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and is involved in the regulation of the heart rate. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in the SAN that links the content of the internal Ca2+ store with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms that regulate the heart rate and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the rice defense system, and that this interaction may be important for the development of Si-based insect pest management strategies. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based insect pest management strategies. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages, as it is in the case of other ether lipid-metabolizing enzymes.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNAs to plants. We also show that the gene silencing efficiency of the DNA nanostructures correlates with the delivery efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

The world’s largest lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can alter the structure and function of coastal ecosystems and threaten the health of human communities. We show that the majority of the nutrients that fuel algal blooms in the nearshore zone of large lakes originate from small tributaries, which are often overlooked in nutrient management efforts. Our findings suggest that small watersheds may be a significant source of nutrients that fuel algal blooms in the nearshore zone of large lakes. Our results highlight the importance of small watersheds in coastal eutrophication and provide a framework for targeting nutrient management efforts to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a strong environmental forcing. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a large-scale bias in the initial conditions is required to explain the observed properties of the universe.

This study offers a new perspective on the mechanisms of action of NMDAR-Abs, which are believed to disrupt receptor function. We show that NMDAR-Abs can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity, which can predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. This study offers insights into the mechanisms of action of NMDAR-Abs, which may be useful in the development of new therapies.

The history of carbon (C) perturbations throughout Earth’s history has been a key focus of the scientific community. However, the history of C perturbations during abrupt climate change events has been largely ignored. Here, we present a study of a major C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C over ∼300 kyr and to near 20% of areal extent of seafloor anoxia. Modeling indicates that the event was linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse. This study provides a key link between the history of C perturbations and the history of climate change. It also provides a potential mechanism for the origin of the “missing carbon” problem.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation in oil palm plantations in Indonesia. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is a useful tool for reducing deforestation in oil palm, but it is not a silver bullet.

The exocytosis process is essential for the transport of molecules from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and the formation of the vacuole. The exocytosis process is tightly regulated, and any disruption in the regulation of the exocytosis process can lead to diseases. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that can inhibit the exocytosis process in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and a potential drug target for diseases related to the exocytosis process. In many vertebrates, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles are segregating within a single species, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes. Here we show that the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii has four possible sex classes: ZZXX females, ZWXX females, ZWXY females, and ZZXY males. We show that the interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation results in modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of the lipid-soluble molecule, vitamin A aldehyde adducts. These adducts are formed by the photooxidation of the lipofuscin, a yellow pigment that accumulates in the retina. We show that the presence of iron in the retina, as in other tissues, is important for the photooxidation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts. This finding has implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly, and other retinal diseases.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of food webs. In this study, we show that the evolution of the feeding strategies of siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is linked to the evolution of their tentacles. Our results show that the evolution of siphonophore specialization is linked to the evolution of the morphology and mode of evolution of their tentacles. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of modern human-like hand morphology and function.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. Here we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target for cancer therapy. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks tumor growth in a mouse model of colon cancer. We also show that the one-carbon donor, formate, is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We show that formate is a critical import of glycine in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These findings provide a rationale for the use of formate in the treatment of cancer, and a target for the development of new cancer therapeutics.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated when forests are fragmented. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries.

Modern farm machinery is the key to the success of modern agriculture, but it has come at a cost of soil compaction. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, which now exceeds safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We also show that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, and that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. Our findings have implications for the design of farm machinery and for the study of prehistoric animals.
